column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction
#Text=The Gas Tungsten Arc Welding ( GTAW ) wire feed additive manufacturing ( AM ) process involves the deposition of metal material using a tungsten arc as an energy source .
#Text=GTAW belongs to the group of Direct Energy Deposit ( DED ) methods in the family of AM processes .
#Text=A solid metal wire is fed through a conventional wire feeder and deposited layer-by-layer onto a substrate .
#Text=The energy source is electrical heating , which melts the metal wire as well as the base material .
#Text=The addition of multiple layers produces a dense near-net-shape part . GTAW wire feed additive manufacturing has a high deposition rate .
#Text=Flexibility and cost savings in manufacturing are important driving forces in the development of such techniques .
#Text=The titanium alloy , Ti-6Al-4V , is extensively used in aerospace applications because of its high strength to weight ratio .
#Text=With an appropriate protective environment to minimize the oxygen content , this alloy shows good weldability and has also been shown to be suitable for additive manufacturing .
#Text=In additive manufacturing , multiple layers are melted on top of each other in a layer-by-layer manner , inducing a number of heating-up/cooling-down cycles in the manufactured material .

#Text=Since Ti-6Al-4V is a two-phase alloy consisting of 90 – 95 % of hcp-α phase and 5 – 10 % bcc-β phase at room temperature , the final microstructure of the material after being additive manufactured can exhibit a variety of microstructures , depending on the conditions of the thermal cycles .

#Text=For the industry to fully adopt additive manufacturing , and to be able to qualify titanium parts for aerospace applications , a complete understanding of the mechanical behavior and control of the resulting properties are prerequisites .

#Text=Process simulations provide information on how to manufacture components in order to achieve the required properties and support the development and understanding of the manufacturing process itself . Finite Element ( FE ) simulations , a conventional method used in the modeling of welding processes , particularly for larger components , are applied on the macro scale .
#Text=In the present work , a validated FE model presented by Lundbäck and Lindgren is used to predict the thermal field that , in turn , determines the microstructural evolution .
#Text=A number of different strategies exist regarding how to include detailed and explicit modeling on a microscopic scale in a macroscopic simulation .

#Text=One such strategy is to use submeshes located at the nodes of the FE model , while another is to use dual-mesh methods that place microstructural domains at the nodes of a macroscopic FE calculation .
#Text=However , with these strategies , the calculations become very cumbersome if a large component is to be simulated .
#Text=Therefore , for industrial needs , it is more pragmatic to use a density type of model , also called the internal state variable approach by Grong and Shercliff .
#Text=In this work , a density-type approach is used in order to model the microstructure on a larger scale .
#Text=Moreover , it facilitates the future combination of the microstructural model with a mechanical model to compute material properties .

#Text=The aim of the present study has been to , for the first time , couple the process simulation model , developed by the authors , with a microstructural model , which has also been developed by the authors , to predict the alpha lath size in the GTAW wire feed AM process .

#Text=The results were validated by building a well-defined , 10-layer-high weld sequence , in which , at specific positions , its microstructural features have been characterized and compared to the predicted results .
